Title.evidence: Randomized prospective studies to quantify the effect of methylprednisolone on perioperative outcomes in neonatal cardiac surgery have not been performed.

Trial_Design.evidence: Neonates scheduled for cardiac surgery were randomly assigned to receive either Two Dose (8 hours preoperatively and operatively; n=39) or Single Dose (operatively; n=37) methylprednisolone (30 mg/kg/dose) in a double-blind, placebo-controlled trial.

Participants.evidence: Neonates scheduled for cardiac surgery were randomly assigned to receive either Two Dose (8 hours preoperatively and operatively; n=39) or Single Dose (operatively; n=37) methylprednisolone (30 mg/kg/dose) in a double-blind, placebo-controlled trial.

Intervention.evidence: Neonates scheduled for cardiac surgery were randomly assigned to receive either Two Dose (8 hours preoperatively and operatively; n=39) or Single Dose (operatively; n=37) methylprednisolone (30 mg/kg/dose) in a double-blind, placebo-controlled trial.

Objective.evidence: We sought to determine whether pre-operative methylprednisolone would improve postoperative recovery in neonates requiring cardiac surgery.

Method_Outcome.evidence: The primary outcome was the incidence of low cardiac output syndrome (standardized score) or death 36 hours postoperatively.

Randomisation_Allocation.evidence: Neonates scheduled for cardiac surgery were randomly assigned to receive either Two Dose (8 hours preoperatively and operatively; n=39) or Single Dose (operatively; n=37) methylprednisolone (30 mg/kg/dose) in a double-blind, placebo-controlled trial.

Number_Analysed.evidence: The incidence of low cardiac output syndrome was 46% (17/37) in the Single Dose and 38% (15/39) in the Two Dose methylprednisolone groups (p=0.51).

Result_Outcome.evidence: The incidence of low cardiac output syndrome was 46% (17/37) in the Single Dose and 38% (15/39) in the Two Dose methylprednisolone groups (p=0.51).

Harms.evidence: Two Dose methylprednisolone was associated with a higher serum creatinine (0.61±0.18 vs. 0.53±0.12 mg/dL, p=0.03), and poorer postoperative diuresis (−96±49 mL, p=0.05).
